content.raw:
Since our qualification award has come in, we can afford to spend money on hardware and/or Amazon instances.  However, it would be nice to have a sense of what is going to be the ideal hardware setup.

Can we get some guidance, and some way of measuring?  It would be nice to use the same sort of hardware as the primary devs, because then presumably we won't get caught up in the sort of timing glitches that plagued the quals.  Is a Xeon class CPU going to be substantially different than a desktop i7?

Also, is there a way to quantify the result?  I've been trying to use a gazebo 'steady state' real time factor as a metric; so just with the initial world, once things settle down, I can get to a real time factor of 0.31 with an Intel GPU and about 0.35 with an Nvidia 755M.  Is that a good metric?  Is it possible to get that real time factor up to 1.0 with the right hardware?  

I have a recollection of Rud spending a lot of money on an expensive GPU, only to find that it didn't provide the hoped for result; I would like to avoid that problem.

Thanks,

Jeremy

values.title: val can't move joints after a fall

content.raw:
we noticed that the high level controller manager somehow stops passing messages to other controllers after a fall. we suspect this has something to do with val not having foot contact. 

this however becomes an issue if we want to make the robot stand back up by itself. 

val's controllers and balance can be sensitive especially in certain configurations and multiple points of contacts with the environment, which causes robot to fall. it's not clear from challenge rules what the consequences of a fall are. 

we would appreciate it if the high level robot controller let at least joint position commands through (even if the IK solvers are disabled until full recovery).

this may sound like a low importance issue, but from a robust mission control stand point it is a big problem.

content.raw:
In trying to determine the current joint states, I am looking at the topic

```
#!python

/ihmc_ros/valkyrie/output/joint_states
```

The topic exists and publishes fine on the local machine where the sim is running.  However, it does not publish over a networked machine, using the standard ROS network setup.  Other things, such as rviz and sending commands work fine.

Other topics, ones that do not use the gazebo world frame, publish fine over the network, for example:

```
#!python

/multisense/joint_states
```

rostopic echo shows that is being published, but only for the hokuyo joint.

values.title: world frame does not go with tf across network

content.raw:
In trying to work as we will in the real run, I am sending commands and receiving data across a network, with one machine running the sim and another doing the commanding.

I am able to use tools like rviz and send commands for joints to move just fine with the typical ROS network setup.  However, the world frame does not exist in tf, it is only from gazebo, so the programs that use transformations from world fail.

How do we get the gazebo world frame over a network connection like we will use for the actual competition?  I could create a transform broadcaster on the sim machine to connect world to pelvis in tf, but I am concerned that that will create conflicts with the world frame that is being broadcast by gazebo.  Also, that would require running a node on the cloud machine during the competition.

For example, the test program walk_test.py fails over a network connection with this error:

```
#!python
python walk_test.py

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "walk_test.py", line 122, in <module>
    walkTest()
  File "walk_test.py", line 28, in walkTest
    msg.footstep_data_list.append(createFootStepOffset(FootstepDataRosMessage.LEFT, [0.2, 0.0, 0.0]))
  File "walk_test.py", line 63, in createFootStepOffset
    footstep = createFootStepInPlace(stepSide)
  File "walk_test.py", line 55, in createFootStepInPlace
    footWorld = tfBuffer.lookup_transform('world', foot_frame, rospy.Time())
  File "/opt/ros/indigo/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/tf2_ros/buffer.py", line 87, in lookup_transform
    return self.lookup_transform_core(target_frame, source_frame, time)
tf2.LookupException: "world" passed to lookupTransform argument target_frame does not exist. 
```

values.title: What is the structure of the final?

content.raw:
I know that some details are still being worked out regarding how the finals will run and some information is available in the [Tutorials](#!/osrf/srcsim/wiki/finals) and User Agreement, but I wonder what the intended structure is of the finals.  Is the following an accurate representation of the structure for the final round?
![SRC_structure.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/2737446776-SRC_structure.png)

What will a final's run look like from the team perspective?  In particular, I'm wondering how the Field Computer (FC) side will run each team's code.  Will someone run it for us when ROS & Gazebo are started?  Should there be a team launch file that someone will run for us on the FC side, or will someone simply run a script if we have a simple python script?

values.title: What will be the difference between the Test and the Finals environment?

content.raw:
So far what I've understood.

On the finals the following will be different:

* 20 second delay on communications

* Limited bandwidth (1-2Mbps for Task 2 & 3, unknown yet for Task 1)

* No /world frame published (from [here](#!/osrf/srcsim/issues/106/world-frame-does-not-go-with-tf-across#comment-35062258))

* New world composition (different places for all the elements)

* No access to Gazebo GUI


Is there any other element that will change in the finals?

* Will any sensor be noisier?

* Will any of the  elements we have to interact with (solar panel, antenna controls, stairs, doors, tools) be of a different shape/color?
content.html:
So far what I've understood.

On the finals the following will be different:

  • 20 second delay on communications

  • Limited bandwidth (1-2Mbps for Task 2 & 3, unknown yet for Task 1)

  • No /world frame published (from here)

  • New world composition (different places for all the elements)

  • No access to Gazebo GUI

Is there any other element that will change in the finals?

  • Will any sensor be noisier?

  • Will any of the elements we have to interact with (solar panel, antenna controls, stairs, doors, tools) be of a different shape/color?

content.raw:
I've developed embedded systems software for decades. As part of that I'm aware of standards that exist for designing equipment. NASA is at the forefront of providing human factors standards. One aspect is to design to avoid confusion so equipment and controls are readily distinguishable especially in emergency situations, e.g. low light or visibility. 

If I were a contractor to NASA developing this software I'd be asking for a lot of changes to make equipment more readily distinguishable. IMO NASA would agree since the changes would be nearly cost free and equally applicable to astronauts when they are on the scene. 

Here are some of the ideas I would suggest:

1. Use brighter colors on the equipment. This dull, blackish, grayish equipment is a poor choice.
2. Use contrasting colors. The satellite dish control panel should be one color and the wheels another color. 
3. Use color to indicate the function of a device. The azimuth control is one color and the elevation another. 
4. Use a standard approach to directions. The satellite wheels should rotate clockwise to increase the number of degrees. 
5. Provide labels and arrows indicating directions. 
6. Color the solar panel box with contrasting colors between the inside and outside. 
7. Color code the leak detector and repair handhelds possibly with contrasting colors on front and back. 
8. Habitat should have contrasting colors on sides. 
9. Use standard positioning, i.e. azimuth should always be on right. 

That a quick list. I suggest / request that some of the equipment in the scenario be changed to reflect these improved operational capabilities.

If I were a contractor to NASA developing this software I'd be asking for a lot of changes to make equipment more readily distinguishable. IMO NASA would agree since the changes would be nearly cost free and equally applicable to astronauts when they are on the scene.

  2. Use contrasting colors. The satellite dish control panel should be one color and the wheels another color.
  3. Use color to indicate the function of a device. The azimuth control is one color and the elevation another.
  4. Use a standard approach to directions. The satellite wheels should rotate clockwise to increase the number of degrees.
  5. Provide labels and arrows indicating directions.
  6. Color the solar panel box with contrasting colors between the inside and outside.

content.raw:
About half the time I have Val turn a wheel, it starts to turn its hand and and then when it touches the wheel itself, the whole robot acts like it got struck by lightening and then collapses to the floor.  I saw this sometimes in phase I when Val's knee would hit the door.

Is this expected behavior or a sim issue?  I wondered if it might be related to exerting too much torque when hitting structure so looked for ways to turn down the torque.  There is a parameter "effort" in the joint states topic, but that is only feedback.  I could not find a way to reduce torque with the ROS messages we are allowed to use.

Anybody else seeing a similar issue?
content.html:

Is this expected behavior or a sim issue? I wondered if it might be related to exerting too much torque when hitting structure so looked for ways to turn down the torque. There is a parameter "effort" in the joint states topic, but that is only feedback. I could not find a way to reduce torque with the ROS messages we are allowed to use.

Anybody else seeing a similar issue?

values.title: What packages will be installed on the Field computer, and can we ask for additional ones?

content.raw:
For example, if we wish to use the ros-indigo-laser-assembler package, which is not installed when you follow the tutorial instructions, how should we accomplish that?

Ideally, we would be told that the field computer will be configured as per the tutorial, and that we are permitted to request the installation of any given ros-indigo package.

The alternate would be for us to include these libraries within our own code.  That is quite doable, but can become a fair pain in the ass when you have a package with a number of dependencies.
content.html:
For example, if we wish to use the ros-indigo-laser-assembler package, which is not installed when you follow the tutorial instructions, how should we accomplish that?

Ideally, we would be told that the field computer will be configured as per the tutorial, and that we are permitted to request the installation of any given ros-indigo package.

The alternate would be for us to include these libraries within our own code. That is quite doable, but can become a fair pain in the ass when you have a package with a number of dependencies.

content.raw:
I have just read the new rules and it shows that the uplink bandwidth for task-1 can be as low as 64 bits per second. This is a very low number considering that the IP header is 192 bits and the UPD header is 64 bits, then at this rate it will take 4 seconds to just transfer the headers. And this does not take into account the headers at the network/interface layer.

So here is my question. Is the uplink bandwidth limit for data only or does it also include all the headers?

values.title: Task-3 Steps are uneven and to small

content.raw:
It looks like the first step and last step are different heights than the middle steps. This would never pass a county builders inspection. The heights should all be the same.

Also, the pads to the steps are not a standard size. In most counties the steps are ~7.25 tall and ~11.00 inches long. It appears that the step length is shorter than the 11.00 and that Val can not get its foot squarely onto a step. Also, the step appears to have a toe kick. With weight always being a concern, I would guess that the toe kick would be eliminated. Without the toe kick Val could place its foot more squarely on the step and have a much higher probability of climbing the steps successfully.

I would recommend that the toe kick be removed and the step dimensions be standardized.

PS Here is an example.

http://images.search.yahoo.com/images/view;_ylt=A0PDoQwjZ8lPqXMAct6JzbkF;_ylu=X3oDMTBlMTQ4cGxyBHNlYwNzcgRzbGsDaW1n?back=http://images.search.yahoo.com/search/images%3Fp%3Dstandard%2Bstair%2Bdimensions%26phrase%3D1%26sado%3D1%26n%3D30%26ei%3Dutf-8%26fr2%3Dsg-gac%26ri%3D37%26tab%3Dorganic%26ri%3D9&w=600&h=568&imgurl=activerain.com/image_store/uploads/9/7/8/7/2/ar128434496327879.jpg&rurl=http://activerain.com/blogsview/1853093/nashville-home-inspection-stair-step-dimensions-9-13-10&size=138.4+KB&name=Nashville+Home+Inspection+-+Stair+Step+Dimensions+-+9.13.10&p=standard+stair+dimensions&oid=68f93205c2ba623cc4fb55850d323ffc&fr2=sg-gac&fr=&tt=Nashville%2BHome%2BInspection%2B-%2BStair%2BStep%2BDimensions%2B-%2B9.13.10&b=0&ni=128&no=9&ts=&tab=organic&sigr=12v7qd21r&sigb=148f4ul6s&sigi=122c0gme3&.crumb=2b8LhfgJIZ4

Sorry for all the edits.

values.title: Ergonomic design of the leak detector and repair tool

content.raw:
As a suggestion, I would have the leak detector and repair tool have a more ergonomic design. Some design attributes would be:

###    1.) Easy to grasp. ###
###    2.) Color code the tool by function. ie leak detector red. repair tool green. ###
###    3.) Create alignment colored strip down the axis of tool. Strip could then be used to get Pose of tool relative to hand. ###
###    4.) Tool would be easy to pick up if it was laying on its side. ie. wide foot and barrel with narrow radius where hand would grasp the tool. ###
###    5.) Easy to use by both human and robot. ###
###    6.) The business end of the tool would be normal to the typical work surface while the hand is in a comfortable natural position. ###

Just some suggestions. Here are a couple of examples.

https://grabcad.com/library/black-decker-codless-drill

https://grabcad.com/library/makita-cordless-drill
content.html:
As a suggestion, I would have the leak detector and repair tool have a more ergonomic design. Some design attributes would be:

1.) Easy to grasp.

2.) Color code the tool by function. ie leak detector red. repair tool green.

3.) Create alignment colored strip down the axis of tool. Strip could then be used to get Pose of tool relative to hand.

4.) Tool would be easy to pick up if it was laying on its side. ie. wide foot and barrel with narrow radius where hand would grasp the tool.

5.) Easy to use by both human and robot.

6.) The business end of the tool would be normal to the typical work surface while the hand is in a comfortable natural position.

Just some suggestions. Here are a couple of examples.

https://grabcad.com/library/black-decker-codless-drill

https://grabcad.com/library/makita-cordless-drill

values.title: Lower real time factor since the update

content.raw:
The RT factor on our fastest computer has dropped from ~0.5 to 0.13 with the latest update using the unique.launch file.

Using the unique_task1.launch it seems to stabilize at 0.48
Using the unique_task2.launch it seems to stabilize at 0.28, I deleted the cable and portable solar panel model and it increased to 0.4

I understand that adding elements to the world increases the number of computations that need to be done, but isn't it  a bit extreme?

This computer has one of the fastest consumer CPU's in the market (i7-7700K CPU @4.20GHz), and is just only able to run it at 0.13RT factor. And probably when it starts walking it will drop even more.

This computer has one of the fastest consumer CPU's in the market (i7-7700K CPU @4.20GHz), and is just only able to run it at 0.13RT factor. And probably when it starts walking it will drop even more.

 Would restarting our client SW a few times, cause gazebo/ros publishers to crash?
 Is there any way to restart Left Image Publisher without restarting gazebo?

***Publishers: None***

***Publishers: 
 * /gazebo (http://127.0.0.1:42879/*)**

content.raw: I am wondering how we are going to localize in the world frame after teleportation.  If we are going to localize using local features and a tool like amcl, then we need a map.  However, the course is randomized, so there is no use in creating a pre-made map of the environment.  Even if we are going to use SLAM, then when you teleport, there is no way to know what the course was between your teleporting locations, so there is no way to localize to the world frame.

values.title: The third joint of the right arm seems to be unstable

content.raw:
The right shoulder yaw seems to be unstable.

If you use the keyboard teleop script, you can fairly readily get the robot to hold a pose where the right arm rocks back and forth, as though that joint is hunting to hold a position.

I haven't seen the left shoulder doing the same action, and you can often 'cure' it by commanding extreme poses, or by using a HandTrajectory message.

I find it fairly easy to reproduce; just start the robot, start the keyboard script, and hit 'uiopjkl'.  Watch the right hand; 9 times out of 10 it will rock back and forth.

values.title: Split messages and services into separate ROS package

content.raw:
The srcsim package contains new messages and services that teams should be able to interact with on the field computer. However, they shouldn't have to install all of the srcsim dependencies (which include gazebo) in order to use them. We should make a separate ROS package with the srcsim messages and switch srcsim to using those.

This would change the message names from `srcsim/Task` to `srcsim_msgs/Task`, so hopefully that doesn't cause too many problems.
content.html:
The srcsim package contains new messages and services that teams should be able to interact with on the field computer. However, they shouldn't have to install all of the srcsim dependencies (which include gazebo) in order to use them. We should make a separate ROS package with the srcsim messages and switch srcsim to using those.

This would change the message names from srcsim/Task to srcsim_msgs/Task, so hopefully that doesn't cause too many problems.

content.raw:
I've been wondering this for a while and thought I'd ask: why is ODE the underlying physics engine for SRC?

I remember that additional physics engines were added to [Gazebo after the VRC](http://gazebosim.org/blog/feature_physics).  I naively imagine that a Featherstone-formulation solver like DART would outperform ODE.  That appears to be the case in @scpeters [2014 ROSCon talk](https://www.osrfoundation.org/wordpress2/wp-content/uploads/2015/04/roscon2014_scpeters.pdf). Is that not the case?  Is it that the IHMC solver is already well-tuned for ODE?  I'm just curious about the rationale.

Thanks,
Steve
content.html:
I've been wondering this for a while and thought I'd ask: why is ODE the underlying physics engine for SRC?

I remember that additional physics engines were added to Gazebo after the VRC. I naively imagine that a Featherstone-formulation solver like DART would outperform ODE. That appears to be the case in @scpeters 2014 ROSCon talk. Is that not the case? Is it that the IHMC solver is already well-tuned for ODE? I'm just curious about the rationale.

Thanks, Steve

content.raw:
I know this is going to be a frustrating issue report, but I want to put it out there in the hope it sparks an 'aha' moment.

On a fairly infrequent basis, I will get Val into a mode where I cannot control some of the fingers.  For example, this morning, I could fully operate the left hand, and I could operate much of the right hand.  I could move the first joint, and I could fully open the hand.  But giving a value for the second joint did not cause the thumb to close in, and my commands to the other fingers mostly worked, but the pinky finger curled oddly, rather than in the normal way.

I've had this happen a few times in the past; other times, after I've gone off and done something else, the hand will magically start working again.  And, as I said, it happens fairly rarely.

But I figured it was worth putting a report out there, in case it helps someone else at some point.

On a fairly infrequent basis, I will get Val into a mode where I cannot control some of the fingers. For example, this morning, I could fully operate the left hand, and I could operate much of the right hand. I could move the first joint, and I could fully open the hand. But giving a value for the second joint did not cause the thumb to close in, and my commands to the other fingers mostly worked, but the pinky finger curled oddly, rather than in the normal way.

I've had this happen a few times in the past; other times, after I've gone off and done something else, the hand will magically start working again. And, as I said, it happens fairly rarely.

But I figured it was worth putting a report out there, in case it helps someone else at some point.

values.title: Walking controller stability decreases as real time factor decreases

content.raw:
The walking controller exhibits increased instability at lower real time factors (such as 0.1).  The attached foot step list is an example.  At higher real time factors (such as 0.5) the attached foot step list will complete successfully, but at lower real time factors the robot will generally fall with the same foot step list.  One of the issues is a knee oscillation around the z axis of the robot.  A sample video of the knee oscillation is attached.  The instability is present both times, but only causes the robot to fall at lower real time factors.  Similar real time factor dependent issues not involving the knee oscillation are also present going up the stairs and are even more problematic there.

This instability means that a solution developed on a smaller world frequently will not work on a larger (slower real time factor) world.

To reproduce:
launch the qual2.launch, run the footstep list and note that it works (at least it should :-).  launch unique.launch, run the identical footstep list and note that the robot generally falls.
content.html:
The walking controller exhibits increased instability at lower real time factors (such as 0.1). The attached foot step list is an example. At higher real time factors (such as 0.5) the attached foot step list will complete successfully, but at lower real time factors the robot will generally fall with the same foot step list. One of the issues is a knee oscillation around the z axis of the robot. A sample video of the knee oscillation is attached. The instability is present both times, but only causes the robot to fall at lower real time factors. Similar real time factor dependent issues not involving the knee oscillation are also present going up the stairs and are even more problematic there.

This instability means that a solution developed on a smaller world frequently will not work on a larger (slower real time factor) world.

To reproduce: launch the qual2.launch, run the footstep list and note that it works (at least it should :-). launch unique.launch, run the identical footstep list and note that the robot generally falls.

values.title: Audit of topics to ensure no cheating allowed

content.raw: This issue is to track an audit of the available topics in the SRC to ensure that none of the available topics can be used to cheat.
content.html: This issue is to track an audit of the available topics in the SRC to ensure that none of the available topics can be used to cheat.

content.raw:
Within the past week, I updated the competition software on two machines and am having issues with walking. I am able to publish to the */ihmc_ros/valkyrie/control/footstep_list* topic (running 'rostopic echo' shows the data being published), however Valkyrie doesn't move.

I have been testing the simulation using the provided *walk_test.py* script. I start the simulation with *roslaunch srcsim unique_task1.launch init:=true*. Then I run the *walk_test.py* script and usually Valkyrie will walk. However, if I try to run the script again in the same simulation instance, Valkyrie doesn't move. The msgs are being published to the topic, but are not executed. There are no errors published by the IHMC controller nor by ROS.

We have a team member who hasn't updated the competition software, and he is able to run the script many times in a single simulation. We are also able to successfully run our walking code.

Currently, we are unable to continue testing our walking code, because this is blocking us on two of our machines. Any information would be greatly appreciated!

values.title: How to query if robot is initialized

content.raw: What is the correct way to query if the robot is initialized and detached from the harness?  This is required so that we don't start our perception nodes when the robot is still in the harness. Given that the docker image can be loaded either before or after initialization, this information is critical.

This is required so that we don't start our perception nodes when the robot is still in the harness. Given that the docker image can be loaded either before or after initialization, this information is critical.

values.title: /ihmc_ros/valkyrie/controller does not subscribe to go_home or stop_all_trajectories

content.raw:
This is a puzzler; I'm posting to keep a record of it, and to see if anyone has any ideas.  I've had this happen to me once before; I don't recall what I did to 'cure' it, but I thought I'd document the issue while I have the failure in front of me, and it's consistent.

That is, for topics we use, we've taken to making sure we have a subscriber.  And as of last night at about 11:30 pm, without any other changes on my part that I'm aware of, the srcsim environment stopped subscribing to these two topics after our field computer publishes them.

Valkyrie also publishes on these topics, and in one run, I saw the controller subscribe to that topic before our code ran.  In another case, both Valkyrie and our code are publishing, but no one is subscribing.

If anyone else has any clues or sign posts, I'd appreciate it.  I'll continue to poke for a bit, but I'll probably have to give up soon, so I can get back to trying to pick things up :-/.
content.html:

That is, for topics we use, we've taken to making sure we have a subscriber. And as of last night at about 11:30 pm, without any other changes on my part that I'm aware of, the srcsim environment stopped subscribing to these two topics after our field computer publishes them.

Valkyrie also publishes on these topics, and in one run, I saw the controller subscribe to that topic before our code ran. In another case, both Valkyrie and our code are publishing, but no one is subscribing.

If anyone else has any clues or sign posts, I'd appreciate it. I'll continue to poke for a bit, but I'll probably have to give up soon, so I can get back to trying to pick things up :-/.

values.title: Box too close to satellite control panel

content.raw: We know there are invalid random worlds where some of the boxes are violating real world physics, but there are also worlds where a box is just too close to the area where the robot is supposed to operate. In the attached example Val's left knee touches the box when she settles into the final position, making her collapse immediately. It seems counterproductive to put equipment where it gets in the way of normal operation. Can teams assume that the worlds picked for the finals will not contain obstacles that block such key places on the map?

content.raw:
I've been working on the docker setup locally with some success, which is amazing. 

**Suggestion:** The docker file "FROM" command uses an existing image as the base for a new image. The example fcomputer uses
```
#!c++

FROM ros:indigo-ros-base
```
to start the docker build. How about creating a base image, *src_base*, that contains the other ROS, OpenCV, IHMC, srcsim, etc software that is going to be used by all of us. This would greatly speed up the deployment to the field computer. Teams could still add more to their image on deployment. I know it works because I just did it locally. 

**Question:** It worked locally but want to check that I having my actual executable in github and executing i, rather than building online, is feasible. Bluntly, I've not been using catkin to build my C++ code and would rather not spend the time retrofitting into the catkin system.

content.raw:
If you do:
roslaunch srcsim unique_task3.launch  init:="true"
then
rosservice call /srcsim/finals/start_task 3 4

You will see some errors like:
[Err] [ContactManager.cc:284] Filter with the same name already exists! Aborting
and the tools on the table will be duplicated.  They also appear to be sort of attached to each other.  It is easiest to see if you try picking up the leak tool with the robot.

Workaround:
rosservice call /srcsim/finals/start_task 3 3
then:
rosservice call /srcsim/finals/start_task 3 4
content.html:
If you do: roslaunch srcsim unique_task3.launch init:="true" then rosservice call /srcsim/finals/start_task 3 4

You will see some errors like: [Err] [ContactManager.cc:284] Filter with the same name already exists! Aborting and the tools on the table will be duplicated. They also appear to be sort of attached to each other. It is easiest to see if you try picking up the leak tool with the robot.

Workaround: rosservice call /srcsim/finals/start_task 3 3 then: rosservice call /srcsim/finals/start_task 3 4

values.title: Foot glitches near table on sample task 2

content.raw:
There appears to be an odd contact behavior that causes the foot to glitch or fall near the table on sample task 2.  I am not sure if it is present elsewhere in other worlds, but it is present in this world.  It does appear to be repeatable.  I have attached a video with collisions and one with contacts to illustrate the issue.  To repeat:

```
#!c++

roslaunch srcsim unique_task2.launch  init:="true"
rosservice call /srcsim/finals/start_task 2 3
take a couple of small steps forward
```
content.html:

I am not sure if it is present elsewhere in other worlds, but it is present in this world. It does appear to be repeatable. I have attached a video with collisions and one with contacts to illustrate the issue. To repeat:

roslaunch srcsim unique_task2.launch  init:="true"
rosservice call /srcsim/finals/start_task 2 3
take a couple of small steps forward

content.raw:
Hi, I am having a very irritating problem. After opening the door to the habitat I am very very regularly having problems with the R5's arm getting caught on the wheel when trying to push the door open.

![arm_caught.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/1535111934-arm_caught.png)

It is not 100% but I would say 75% of the time if my arm comes in contact with the wheel then I get hung up and it drags the R5 down.  The  door needs to be open to 90 degrees from its starting position so it really has to be pushed, and even then the width of that entry way is pretty tight. 

Anyone else having this problem?
content.html:
Hi, I am having a very irritating problem. After opening the door to the habitat I am very very regularly having problems with the R5's arm getting caught on the wheel when trying to push the door open.

It is not 100% but I would say 75% of the time if my arm comes in contact with the wheel then I get hung up and it drags the R5 down. The door needs to be open to 90 degrees from its starting position so it really has to be pushed, and even then the width of that entry way is pretty tight.

Anyone else having this problem?

values.title: Can you check contacts for cable joints too?

content.raw:
I'm finding that the solar array cable joints are far more potent that I would expect; they often get caught up on the array, and bind in surprising ways.

Could this be a 'trimesh-trimesh' contact issue as well?

values.title: multisense_state_publisher and robot_state_publisher publish conflicting TF for MS lidar

content.raw:
I want to make sure everything is kosher with how I'm getting the multisense lidar to work.  The issue is that both the `robot_state_publisher` (subscribed to `/ihmc_ros/valkyrie/output/joint_states`) and `multisense_state_publisher` are both publishing a TF transform for the lidar.  However, `/ihmc_ros/valkyrie/output/joint_states` always has a zero angle for the lidar, so they fight [as shown here](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BvZK49Wzt3A)


There's a workaround from #15 (see the last post); I have something similar in my bringup launch file.  The worry is that it ends up replacing the `robot_state_publisher` running on the sim machine with my own version, subscribed instead to `/hardware_joint_states` and `/multisense/joint_states`.

Ultimately, my question is: will we have access to `/hardware_joint_states` and is it okay to run my own `robot_state_publisher` which forces the one on the sim machine to shut down? Or is it worth fixing at this point?


To reproduce -- nothing of mine running, just srcsim:
```
roslaunch srcsim unique_task1.launch init:=true
rostopic pub /multisense/set_spindle_speed std_msgs/Float64 "data: 1.0" 
```
content.html:
I want to make sure everything is kosher with how I'm getting the multisense lidar to work. The issue is that both the robot_state_publisher (subscribed to /ihmc_ros/valkyrie/output/joint_states) and multisense_state_publisher are both publishing a TF transform for the lidar. However, /ihmc_ros/valkyrie/output/joint_states always has a zero angle for the lidar, so they fight as shown here

There's a workaround from #15 (see the last post); I have something similar in my bringup launch file. The worry is that it ends up replacing the robot_state_publisher running on the sim machine with my own version, subscribed instead to /hardware_joint_states and /multisense/joint_states.

Ultimately, my question is: will we have access to /hardware_joint_states and is it okay to run my own robot_state_publisher which forces the one on the sim machine to shut down? Or is it worth fixing at this point?

To reproduce -- nothing of mine running, just srcsim:

roslaunch srcsim unique_task1.launch init:=true
rostopic pub /multisense/set_spindle_speed std_msgs/Float64 "data: 1.0"

values.title: Final Competition Worlds Quite Different from Test Worlds?

content.html:
@chapulina Could you elaborate on your statement from Issue 196? I keep hearing implications that in the test worlds we are not seeing the full variability that might appear in the final worlds.

Ah so I think you didn't see the issue on the other tasks because they happened to be aligned with the world. But don't count on this, because during the finals, they will probably have different orientations on each world.

This particular statement implies, IMO, that while the test worlds are all facing the +X axis that this may not be the case in the final worlds. If so, how do we create worlds for testing? How can we create worlds for testing the other parameters that may be different?

values.title: How will the bandwidth restriction changes be implemented over a single run?

content.raw:
I see in the rules that the new bandwidth/latency will be communicated to teams before they start each task.
```
Shortly in advance of each run, teams will be told what bandwidth 
limitations will be in place for the run. Bandwidth changes at the 
task transition points will be communicated to teams when they 
reach the task completion boxes.
```
How will the change in the bandwidth be implemented?  I imagine the simulator will continue to run and just new parameters will be sent to `tc`?  Will this happen as Val leaves the previous task completion box?  When will the bandwidth restriction start for task 1?  On startup, or when we leave the task box?

I ask because these changes are likely to require reconfiguring/restarting our comms solution after they occur, so best to plan for it now.

Thanks!
